record_data.record_plain_text:
FERC ICA Oil Tariff F.E.R.C. No. 1.0.0
GRIEVE PIPELINE, LLC
GRIEVE PIPELINE CRUDE OIL SYSTEM
LOCAL AND PROPORTIONAL PIPELINE TARIFF
CONTAINING
RULES AND REGULATIONS
GOVERNING THE TRANSPORTATION AND HANDLING
OF
CRUDE OIL
TRANSPORTED BY CARRIER’S PIPELINE
FROM AND TO POINTS NAMED HEREIN
This Tariff shall apply to those Tariffs which specifically incorporate this Tariff by reference; such reference includes supplements to this Tariff and successive reissues thereof.
The rates and transportation named in this Tariff are expressed in cents per Barrel of 42 U.S. Gallons and are subject to change as provided by law.
The matter published herein will have no adverse effect on the quality of the human environment.
ISSUED: January 29, 2018 EFFECTIVE: February 28, 2018
Issued By: V. Brian Dolan Vice President Grieve Pipeline, LLC 1700 Lincoln Suite 2950 Denver, CO 80203 Tel: 303.861.6255 Ext. 2916 Brian.Dolan@elkpet.com <mailto:Brian.Dolan@elkpet.com> Compiled By: V. Brian Dolan Vice President Grieve Pipeline, LLC 1700 Lincoln Suite 2950 Denver, CO 80203 Tel: 303.861.6255 Ext. 2916 Brian.Dolan@elkpet.com <mailto:Brian.Dolan@elkpet.com>
GENERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS
TARIFF REISSUE AND SUPPLEMENTATION
RULE 1 – METHOD OF CANCELING RULES
As this Tariff is supplemented, numbered rules with letter suffixes cancel corresponding numbered rules in the original Tariff or in a supplement. Letter suffixes will be used in alphabetical sequence starting with “A.”
Example – Rule 60-A cancels Rule 60; and Rule 90-B cancels 90-A in a prior supplement which, in turn, canceled Rule 90.
RULE 2 – METHOD OF DENOTING REISSUED MATTERS IN SUPPLEMENTS
Matters brought forward without change from one supplement to another will be redesignated as “Reissued” by a reference mark in the form of a square enclosing a number, the number being that of the supplement in which the reissued matter first appeared in its currently effective form. To determine the supplement’s original effective date, refer to the explanation of reference marks in the supplement. For further details, consult the supplement in which the reissued matter first became effective.
RULE 3 – REFERENCE TO NOTES, RULES, ETC.
When reference is made in this Tariff, and supplements thereto, to notes, rules, etc., such references are continuous and include supplements to and successive reissuances of such notes, rules, etc.
DEFINITIONS
RULE 4 – DEFINITIONS
“Actual Shipment” means the volumes of Crude Oil physically Tendered at a Receipt Point by an individual Shipper during a month under this Tariff.
“API” means American Petroleum Institute.
“ASTM” means American Society for Testing Materials.
“Average Monthly Volumes” shall mean the average of a Regular Shipper’s monthly volumes of Crude Oil transported during the Base Period.
“Barrel” means 42 gallons at 60 degrees Fahrenheit and zero (0) gauge pressure if the vapor pressure is at or below atmospheric pressure, or at equilibrium pressure if the vapor pressure is above atmospheric pressure.
“Base Period” means the previous 12 months beginning with the 13th month prior to the current Proration Month, except that, during the initial 12 months of this Tariff’s operation, the Base Period shall be as provided in Rule 15(e). Previous Proration Months, as well as months in which no apportionment was in effect, will be included in the rolling 12-month Base Period.
“Batch,” “Batched,” or “Batched Shipments” means transportation of Crude Oil that is tendered at the Receipt Point pursuant to a TA in which Shipper has provided or arranged for adequate storage at a location(s) and capacity(ies) which, in Carrier’s sole discretion, are sufficient to permit Carrier to physically segregate Shipper’s volumes for Delivery.
“Carrier” means Grieve Pipeline, LLC.
“Carrier’s Pipeline” means Carrier’s Crude Oil pipeline facilities originating at the Receipt Point(s) and terminating at the Delivery Point(s) as reflected in the Rates Tariff, as may be amended from time to time.
“Committed Shipper” means a Shipper that has either dedicated acreage or made long-term volume commitments in the Open Season and has executed a Transportation Agreement with Carrier. A Committed Shipper is not subject to the prorationing provisions in Rule 15.
“Committed Volume” means for a Committed Shipper either the (i) barrel per day (“bpd”) volume Committed multiplied by the number of days in the relevant month or (ii) the Monthly Maximum Quantity dedicated to such Shipper, in accordance with a TA.
“Common Stream” or “Common Stream Shipment” means Crude Oil, tendered or received at Carrier’s Pipeline and associated facilities as designated in the related tariffs and moved through Carrier’s Pipeline, which is commingled or intermixed with other Crude Oil of like characteristics and quality. A Common Stream may be made up of one or more tenders of Crude Oil provided that each tender of Crude Oil meets the quality specifications, as set out in Rule 6. Common Streams and characteristics of each shall be determined by Carrier in its sole discretion.
“Consignee” means the party that Shipper has authorized to accept the Delivery from Carrier of Crude Oil at the Delivery Point.
“Crude Oil” means crude oil or condensate, as appropriate.
“Day” means a period beginning at 7:00 A.M. Mountain Time on a calendar day and ending at 7:00 A.M. Mountain Time on the next succeeding calendar day. The date of a Day shall be that of its beginning.
“Delivery,” “Deliver,” “Deliveries,” or “Delivered” means the transfer of physical and legal custody of Crude Oil from Carrier at the Delivery Point to Shipper or its Consignee.
“Delivery Point” means the point(s) of Delivery, as specified in the Rates Tariff .
“Exempt Volumes” shall have the meaning set forth in Rule 15(a).
“FERC” means the U.S. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and any lawful successor agency thereto.
“Gravity” means gravity determined in accordance with ASTM Designation D-287.
“Maximum Monthly Quantity” means the maximum monthly volume of a Carrier’s Pipeline delivery capacity that Carrier has committed to provide to a Committed Shipper in a TA.
“Month” means a period beginning at 7:00 A.M. Mountain Time on the first Day of a calendar month and ending at 7:00 A.M. Mountain Time on the first Day of the next succeeding calendar month.
“New Shipper” means, for purposes of prorationing in Rule 15, any Shipper who does not qualify as a Committed Shipper or Regular Shipper.
“Nomination” means a request by a Shipper to Carrier of a stated volume of Crude Oil for transportation from the Receipt Point to the Delivery Point in accordance with this Tariff.
“Open Season” means the FERC open season process conducted by Carrier with respect to obtaining long-term volume commitments and/or acreage dedications from Committed Shippers on Carrier’s Pipeline.
“Priority Capacity” means, for any Proration Month, ninety percent (90%) of System Capacity.
“Proration Month” shall have the meaning set forth in Rule 15(b).
“Rates Tariff” means Carrier’s tariff that sets forth the local and proportional rates and transportation fee applicable to the transportation of Crude Oil by Carrier and that makes specific reference by FERC number to this Tariff.
“Receipt,” “Receive,” or “Received” means the transfer of physical and legal custody of Crude Oil from Shipper to Carrier at the Receipt Point for transportation.
“Receipt Point” means the points of Receipt, as specified in the Rates Tariff.
“Regular Shipper” means, for purposes of prorationing in Rule 15, (i) a Shipper that has shipments in at least six (6) months in the Base Period or (ii) a Committed Shipper’s Nominations that are in excess of its Committed Volumes.
“Shipper” means the party that arranges with Carrier for the gathering or transportation of Crude Oil pursuant to the terms of this Tariff.
“Shipper History” means the deliveries made by a Shipper during the most current Base Period.
“Shipper Indemnified Party” and “Shipper Indemnified Parties” has the meaning set forth in Rule 25.
“System Capacity” means the total volume of Crude Oil that Carrier’s Pipeline is capable of transporting under existing conditions.
“TA” means a Transportation Agreement executed by Carrier and a Committed Shipper, entered into as a result of an Open Season conducted by Carrier.
“TA Committed Capacity” means the barrel per day capacity equal to the aggregate Committed Volumes pursuant to all Committed Shippers’ TAs in effect during the month of prorationing.
“Tender”, “Tendered”, “Tendering” and “Tenders” means the delivery by a Shipper to Carrier of a volume of Crude Oil at the Receipt Point for transportation to the Delivery Point in accordance with this Tariff.
“Total Available Capacity” means all of the operationally available capacity to Shippers on Carrier’s Pipeline.
COMMODITY DESCRIPTION AND MEASUREMENT
RULE 5 – COMMODITY
The Carrier is engaged in the transportation of Crude Oil and will not accept any other commodity for transportation.
RULE 6 – CRUDE OIL QUALITY SPECIFICATIONS AND RESTRICTIONS Carrier shall have the right to refuse Crude Oil that fails to meet Carrier’s specifications below or the specifications established by interconnecting carriers directly downstream of the Delivery Point. Carrier’s quality specifications are the following;
(a) a maximum temperature of 100ºF;
(b) a maximum pressure of 60 psig;
(c) a minimum pressure required to flow Crude Oil into Carrier’s Pipeline;
(d) a maximum Gravity of 50 API and a minimum of 30 API;
(e) a maximum sulphur content not to exceed 0.50% by weight;
(f) the Reid vapor pressure of the Crude Oil shall not exceed eleven and half (11.5) pounds at 100°F;
(g) the true vapor pressure of the Crude Oil shall not exceed the limits regarding hydrocarbon emissions as established by applicable law;
(h) the Crude Oil cannot contain impurities exceeding 0.5% including not more than 0.2% water; and
(i) the Crude Oil cannot be contaminated by the presence of any chemicals foreign to virgin crude oil including, but not limited to, chlorinated and/or oxygenated hydrocarbons and lead.
Crude Oil delivered to Carrier that does not meet these specifications shall be considered off-spec. If upon investigation Carrier determines that a Shipper has delivered off-spec Crude Oil, such Shipper may be excluded from further entry into applicable segments of the system until such time as quality specifications are met.
Carrier reserves the right to reject Crude Oil that, on an equitable and non-discriminatory basis, does not meet the quality specifications referenced above. In addition, Carrier shall reject Crude Oil containing contaminants including, but not limited to, chemicals such as chlorinated and/or oxygenated hydrocarbons and/or heavy metals such as lead and/or vanadium. Carrier reserves the right to reject Crude Oil if Deliveries of such volumes would not meet the tariff quality specifications required at the Delivery Point. If Crude Oil is accepted from third-party owned tankage, settled bottoms in such tanks must not be above a point six inches (6”) below the bottom of the pipeline connection with the tank. Carrier reserves the right to reject Crude Oil, on an equitable and non-discriminatory basis, if the Shipper or Consignee has failed to comply with applicable laws, rules, and regulations made by government authorities regulating shipment of Crude Oil. If, upon investigation, Carrier determines that a Shipper has delivered off-spec Crude Oil, Carrier may exclude, on an equitable and non-discriminatory basis, such Shipper from further entry into applicable segments of Carrier’s Pipeline until such Shipper is able to comply with the quality specifications referenced above. If Carrier Receives off-spec Crude Oil at the Receipt Point, it shall Deliver such Crude Oil to Shipper or Consignee at the Delivery Point. Carrier may, on an equitable and non-discriminatory basis, from time to time, undertake to transport other or additional grades of Crude Oil as operating conditions permit. Carrier shall transport such other or additional grades of Crude Oil that do not meet the specifications set forth above in Batch Shipments. If sufficient quantities are not Nominated or facilities are not available to justify continued transportation of other or additional grades, Carrier may, on an equitable and non-discriminatory basis, after giving reasonable notice to Shippers who may be affected, cease transporting particular grades of Crude Oil. RULE 7 – TESTING AND MEASURING
Prior to or during Receipt of Crude Oil for transportation, and prior to or during release thereof for Delivery, such quantities shall be measured and tested by a representative of Carrier. Crude Oil will be measured by metering. Shipper shall be allowed to be present or represented at the measurement and testing. Quantities shall be measured by meters and calculated in accordance with applicable A.P.I. Manual of Petroleum Measurement Standards.
RULE 8 – DEDUCTIONS AND ADJUSTMENTS
In measuring the quantity of Crude Oil Received and Delivered, corrections shall be made from volumes at actual or observed temperature to volumes at 60 degrees Fahrenheit and for pressure to 14.696 psia. Quantities shall be corrected for this purpose by use of applicable API-ASTM volume correction factor tables.
For all shipments of Crude Oil, a deduction of one-quarter of one percent (0.25%) will be made to cover evaporation, interface losses, and other normal losses during transportation. Carrier will deduct the full amount of sediment, water, and other impurities. The net balance, after applicable deduction, will be the quantity deliverable by Carrier. To address certain Gravity and quality differences within the Common Stream, Carrier may, at its reasonable discretion, establish a Gravity and quality bank to calculate, collect, and remit monetary adjustments among all Shippers tendering within the Common Stream. RULE 9 – VOLUMETRIC ADJUSTMENT Any volumetric difference between Receipts from Shipper and Delivery to Shipper or Consignee during a current month as a result of scheduling will be adjusted in the following month without any further liability to Carrier, taking into consideration all prior deductions allowed pursuant to the rules and regulations contained herein. RULE 10 – VARIATIONS IN QUALITY AND GRAVITY
(a) Delivery of Types of Crude Oil. Carrier is not obligated to Deliver the identical Crude Oil Received by Carrier. Shippers acknowledge that the Crude Oil Tendered to Carrier may be subject to mixing with Crude Oil Tendered by other Shippers into the Common Stream. For Batched Shipments, Carrier shall not be liable for any change in quality and/or Gravity that may occur to Crude Oil during transportation of Batches. (b) Changes in Specifications and Types of Crude Oil. If the Crude Oil Tendered is of a type or quality other than that being transported at the time of the Tender, and subject to such Crude Oil meeting the specifications set out in Rule 6, as operating conditions permit, at the request of the Shipper, Carrier may transport and Deliver such volumes by Batched Shipments; provided that Shipper agrees to provide any additional facilities required by Carrier to support such Batched Shipments, as determined by Carrier in its sole discretion. (c) CARRIER MAKES NO WARRANTY AS TO MERCHANTABILITY, FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE, OR ANY OTHER WARRANTY OR REPRESENTATION WITH RESPECT TO THE GRADE OR QUALITY OF CRUDE OIL TRANSPORTED UNDER THIS TARIFF. PRE-SHIPMENT REQUIREMENTS AND PROCEDURES RULE 11 – NOMINATION
Shippers desiring to offer Crude Oil for transportation shall make a Nomination to Carrier by submitting, on Carrier’s prescribed Notice of Shipment form, a separate Nomination for each calendar month on or before the 25th day of the preceding month. The prescribed Notice of Shipment form, in addition, must provide a verification that the Shipper intends, after Delivery to the Delivery Point, its volumes will be transported by other carriers (including by pipeline, rail, and/or water) across state lines to its ultimate destination and, therefore, the transportation on Carrier’s Pipeline is interstate in nature and subject to this Tariff. If transportation capacity is available and operating conditions permit, Carrier, on an equitable and non-discriminatory basis, may accept Nominations for Crude Oil for transportation after the 25th day of the month preceding the month during which the transportation under the Nomination is to begin.
If, during a month in which Nominations have not been prorated pursuant to Rule 15, Carrier determines that a Shipper is not Tendering the volumes that it has nominated for that month, then Carrier reserves the right to reduce such Shipper’s Nomination accordingly for the balance of such month.
RULE 12 – CREDITWORTHINESS OF SHIPPER
Upon the request of the Carrier, all prospective and existing Shippers must submit sufficient financial information to establish creditworthiness. If Carrier determines, on an equitable and non-discriminatory basis, that a prospective Shipper is not creditworthy, or if a Shipper’s credit deteriorates, Carrier may require such Shippers to provide financial assurances, including, but not limited to: (a) prepayment of transportation charges; (b) a guaranty in an amount sufficient to ensure payment to Carrier of all such costs and charges that could reasonably accrue, in a form and from a third party acceptable to Carrier; (c) a letter of credit from an appropriate financial institution in a form acceptable to Carrier and in an amount sufficient to ensure payment to Carrier of all costs and charges that could reasonably accrue; or (d) such other enforceable collateral security, including but not limited to, security agreements over assets of Shipper, in a form acceptable to Carrier.
Carrier shall not be obligated to accept Crude Oil, or a Nomination, for transportation from an existing or prospective Shipper if the Shipper or prospective Shipper fails to provide financial assurances within ten (10) days of Shipper’s receipt of Carrier’s written request for such assurance.
RULE 13 – TITLE
A Tender for shipment shall be deemed a warranty of title by Shipper, but acceptance shall not be deemed a representation by Carrier as to title. Carrier reserves the right to reject on a non-discriminatory basis any Crude Oil Tendered for shipment that may be involved in litigation, the title of which may be in dispute, or that may be encumbered by lien or charge of any kind, except to the extent that Shipper submits either satisfactory proof of unencumbered title or a satisfactory indemnity bond.
Carrier may not encumber or lien Shipper’s Crude Oil except as specifically set forth in this Tariff or the relevant TA. RULE 14 – QUANTITIES
Carrier may take Receipt or make Delivery of Crude Oil in volumes of not less than 500 bpd aggregate from one or more Shippers. The Carrier reserves the right, on a non-discriminatory basis, to take Receipt or make Delivery of less than 500 bpd of Crude Oil, if such quantity can be consolidated with other Crude Oil such that Carrier can make a single delivery of not less than 500 bpd.
RULE 15 – PRORATIONING OF PIPELINE CAPACITY
(a) Exempt Volumes. Each Committed Shipper’s Committed Volumes are exempt from the prorationing procedures, as set forth below (“Exempt Volumes”). If a Committed Shipper’s Nominations during a Proration Month are less than its Committed Volumes, the Committed Shipper’s Exempt Volumes for that month will be limited to the amount of its Nominations. Nominations above a Committed Shipper’s Committed Volumes (“Excess Volumes”) shall be treated as volumes nominated by a Regular Shipper, as described below.
(b) Prorationing. When, based upon all valid Nominations submitted by Shippers in compliance with this Tariff, Carrier determines that the total volumes nominated by all Shippers for shipment on Carrier’s Pipeline during that month exceed the capacity of Carrier’s Pipeline or a particular segment thereof (“Proration Month”), then the available capacity remaining after the satisfaction of all Exempt Volumes nominated will be apportioned among all valid Shipper Nominations on the basis set forth below:
1. Up to ten percent (10%) of System Capacity will be allocated among all New Shippers. When the Nominations made by New Shippers exceed ten percent (10%) of the available System Capacity, each New Shipper will receive a pro rata portion of the ten percent (10%) allocated to New Shippers.
2. The Priority Capacity will be allocated to Committed Shippers so that each Committed Shipper is allocated capacity in an amount equal to its Committed Volumes. A Committed Shipper’s Exempt Volumes will be treated as a Regular Shipper with respect to such Excess Volumes.
3. The proration factor for Regular Shippers shall be the net of the System Capacity less the allocated New Shipper volumes and the Exempt Volumes divided by the Regular Shippers’ Nominations.
4. Any remaining System Capacity will be allocated among all Regular Shippers based on each Regular Shipper’s Average Monthly Volumes during the Base Period or nominated volume, whichever is less. Remaining unallocated System Capacity shall continue to be reallocated to all Regular Shippers until all System Capacity is allocated or Regular Shippers’ Nominations have been fulfilled.
5. Remaining System Capacity will be allocated on a pro rata basis among remaining Regular Shipper and New Shipper unallocated Tenders.
No Nominations shall be accepted beyond the amount that the nominating party has readily accessible for shipment.
(c) Transfer of prorated capacity. Except as provided in Rule 15, prorated volumes allocated to a Shipper may not be assigned, conveyed, loaned, transferred to, or used in any manner by another Shipper. A Shipper’s allocation may be transferred as an incident of a sale or transfer of the Shipper’s business or to a successor to the Shipper’s business by the operation of law, such as an executor or trustee in bankruptcy.
(d) Nomination Integrity. During a Proration Month, if a Shipper fails to Tender to Carrier at least ninety (90%) of its final confirmed Nomination, Carrier will charge the Shipper an amount equal to the tariff rate multiplied by the nominated volume not received by Carrier.
(e) Transition rule for determining Base Period. During the initial 12 months of this Tariff's implementation, as measured from the effective date hereof (“Tariff Effective Date”), the Base Period shall consist of each full calendar month since the Tariff Effective Date, but prior to the Proration Month. For example, if the Proration Month were to occur in the 7th month from the Tariff Effective Date, the Base Period would consist of the first 6 months from the Tariff Effective Date. In all other respects, Rule 15(a)-(d) remains in effect during the initial 12 months of this Tariff's implementation. This transition rule shall have no effect on and after the 13th full calendar month from the Tariff Effective Date. TRANSPORTATION SERVICES AND RELATED REQUIREMENTS
RULE 16 – RECEIPT AND DELIVERY POINT FACILITIES REQUIRED
Carrier only provides working tankage that is incidental and necessary to the transportation of Crude Oil, but does not provide or offer storage service, whether in transit or/at points of Receipt or the Delivery Point. Nominations for the transportation of Crude Oil will be accepted only when Shipper has provided, or arranged for access to, equipment and facilities capable of satisfactorily delivering to the Receipt Point and receiving at the Delivery Point the quantities tendered for transportation. Shipper will deliver to the Receipt Point nominated volumes on a ratable basis over the course of a month. Carrier, where operations permit, may waive such ratable delivery requirement on a non-discriminatory basis.
No duty to transport shall arise until Shipper furnishes to Carrier documentation sufficient to demonstrate that Shipper has provided, or arranged for access to, the necessary equipment and facilities immediately downstream of the Delivery Point.
RULE 17 – PIPEAGE OR OTHER CONTRACTS In the event construction of new facilities is required to provide transportation service to a Shipper, separate pipeage and other contracts may be required of a Shipper, in accordance with the applicable Tariff and these rules, before any duty of transportation by Carrier shall arise. A pipeage contract may include additional charges for reimbursement for facilities necessary to Receive or Deliver Shipper’s Crude Oil. RULE 18 – LINE FILL AND WORKING STOCK REQUIREMENT
Carrier shall provide, be responsible for, own, and maintain Carrier’s Pipeline line fill and working stock necessary for efficient operation of Carrier’s Pipeline.
RULE 19 – DELIVERY AND DEMURRAGE
After any shipment has arrived at the Delivery Point, Carrier may begin Delivery at its current rate of pumping. Since Carrier does not own or operate storage or tankage facilities for Shipper storage purposes, it is essential that Shipper or its Consignee promptly accept any shipment offered for Delivery. A demurrage charge of $0.01 per barrel shall accrue for each day on which any part of said shipment offered for Delivery is not promptly taken by Shipper or its Consignee.
In the event that Shipper or its Consignee fails to promptly accept any shipment offered for Delivery or any portion thereof, then Carrier shall also have the right to divert, reconsign, or make whatever arrangements for disposition of the subject Crude Oil that it deems appropriate to clear its pipeline facilities, including the right to sell the subject Crude Oil at private or public sale. Carrier may be a purchaser at any such sale. From the proceeds of any such sale, Carrier may pay itself all transportation and other charges and expenses in caring for and maintaining the subject Crude Oil and the costs of sale, and the balance shall be held for whomsoever may be lawfully entitled thereto.
RULE 20 – EVIDENCE OF RECEIPTS AND DELIVERIES
The Receipt and Delivery shall be evidenced, in each instance, by a statement showing the quantities Received or Delivered as the case may be, temperature, basic sediment and water, and any other data essential to the determination of quantity.
In further detail, Carrier shall furnish Shipper a monthly statement showing (i) the total quantity of Crude Oil Received hereunder during the preceding Month at each Receipt Point, (ii) the total quantity of Crude Oil Delivered hereunder during the preceding Month at the Delivery point, and (iii) an itemization of the transportation fees and any additional fees chargeable to Shipper hereunder.
RULE 21 – RATES APPLICABLE
Crude Oil Received by Carrier for transportation shall be subject to the rates, additional fees (if applicable), and transportation fees in effect on the date of Receipt by Carrier, irrespective of the date of Nomination.
RULE 22 – PAYMENT OF TRANSPORTATION AND OTHER CHARGES
Transportation and all other lawful charges will be collected on the basis of net volume of Crude Oil Received at the Receipt Point. Shipper shall be responsible for payment of transportation and all other charges applicable to the shipment, and per Rule 12, may be required to prepay such charges or furnish guaranty of payment to Carrier. Carrier shall not be deemed to be the purchaser or the lessee or operator who has responsibility under W.S.1977 § 30-5-301 et. seq. All payments are due on the 20th Day of the Month (if the 20th falls on a Saturday, then due on the 19th, or if it falls on a Sunday, then due on the 21st) following the receipt by Shipper of the monthly invoice provided under Rule 20. Carrier shall have a lien on all Crude Oil in its possession belonging to the Shipper to secure the payment of all unpaid charges due by such Shipper, and may withhold such Crude Oil from Delivery until all of such unpaid charges shall have been paid. If any charge remains unpaid after the due date specified in Carrier’s invoice, then such amount shall bear interest from the day after the date of the invoice until paid, calculated at an annual rate equivalent to 125% of the prime rate of interest, as of the date of Carrier’s invoice, charged by the Citibank N.A. of New York, New York, for ninety (90) day loans made to substantial and responsible commercial borrowers or the maximum rate allowed by law, whichever is the lesser.
If said charges shall remain unpaid ten (10) days after the date that Shipper’s payment is due as set forth above, or, in the absence of unpaid charges, when there shall be failure to take the Crude Oil at the Delivery Point as provided in these rules and regulations, Carrier may take action to enforce its lien rights set forth above. RULE 23 – CHARGES FOR SPILL COMPENSATION ACTS AND REGULATIONS
In addition to the transportation charges and all other charges accruing on Crude Oil accepted for transportation, a per barrel charge will be assessed and collected in the amount of any tax, fee, or other charge levied against Carrier by any federal, state, or local act or regulation for the purpose of creating a fund for the prevention, containment, cleanup and/or removal of spills and/or the reimbursement of persons sustaining loss therefrom. If such a tax, fee or other charge is levied against Carrier, Carrier shall file with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to place into effect a per barrel rate to recover such tax, fee, or other charge. Carrier shall be under no obligation to contest or protest on behalf of Shipper or its Consignee the legality of such tax, fee, or other charges. Shipper shall be entitled to protest any rate proposed to recover such tax, fee or other charge. LIABILITY AND CLAIMS
RULE 24 – DUTY OF CARRIER
Carrier shall transport and Deliver the quantity of Crude Oil accepted for transportation (less the appropriate deductions), with reasonable diligence, considering the quantity of Crude Oil, the distance of transportation, the safety of operation, and other material factors.
RULE 25 – LIABILITY OF CARRIER
(a) Except as discussed in this Rule 25, Carrier shall not be liable or responsible to any party for any delay, damage or loss, whether to property or person, including fines or penalties, resulting from any cause while Carrier is in possession or control of such Shipper’s Crude Oil, including the breakdown of the facilities of Carrier’s Pipeline.
(b) Other than as set forth in Rule 8, Carrier shall bear the risk of loss for Shipper’s Crude Oil while it is in Carrier’s possession or control.
(c) Carrier shall release, indemnify, defend, and hold harmless Shipper and its affiliates and their respective directors, officers, equity owners, employees, agents, consultants, and other advisor and representatives (each, a “Shipper Indemnified Party” and collectively, “Shipper Indemnified Parties”) from and against, and will pay to Shipper Indemnified Parties the value of all losses, liabilities and obligations caused by, related to, attributable to or arising out of any leaks or spills from Carrier’s Pipeline from any cause, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE FAULT, NEGLIGENCE, OR STRICT, PREEXISTING OR OTHER LIABILITY ON THE PART OF A THIRD PARTY, SHIPPER OR CARRIER; provided that, any leak or spill caused by, related to, attributable to or arising in whole or in part due to gross negligence on the part of Shipper shall limit Carrier’s indemnification obligation to the extent the liability or obligation is attributable to Shipper’s gross negligence.
(d) NOTWITHSTANDING ANYTHING TO THE CONTRARY IN THIS TARIFF, NEITHER SHIPPER NOR CARRIER BE LIABLE OR RESPONSIBLE TO THE OTHER PARTY, ITS AFFILIATES, SUCCESSORS IN INTEREST, BENEFICIARIES OR ASSIGNEES, FOR ANY CONSEQUENTIAL, INCIDENTAL, INDIRECT, SPECIAL, OR PUNITIVE DAMAGES, OR FOR LOSS OF PROFITS OR REVENUES, THAT ARISE IN RELATION TO THE TRANSPORTATION OF CRUDE OIL UNDER THIS TARIFF, REGARDLESS OF WHETHER SUCH CLAIM ARISES UNDER OR RESULTS FROM CONTRACT, TORT, OR STRICT LIABILITY.
RULE 26 – LIABILITY OF SHIPPER
To the fullest extent permitted by applicable law, Shipper shall indemnify, defend, and hold Carrier harmless from any and all personal injuries, property damage (including full or partial loss of use of property), damages, claims, suits, costs and recoveries, fines, penalties and expenses (including reasonable attorneys’ fees and expenses) of any kind or character arising from, or related to, grossly negligent or willful acts, breaches of warranties and representations, or omissions on the part of Shipper Indemnified Parties with respect to any Crude Oil Tendered by Shipper and transported by Carrier pursuant to this Tariff. In the event of any suit or action brought against Carrier for any of the foregoing, Shipper shall appear and defend against any such suit or action and pay any judgment that may be obtained against Carrier. Except as provided in Rule 25, where personal injury, death, or physical loss of or physical damage to property is the result of the joint negligence or misconduct of both the Carrier and Shipper, both parties shall indemnify each other in proportion to their respective share of such joint negligence or misconduct, as limited by Shipper’s indemnification obligations set forth in this Rule 26.
RULE 27 – CLAIMS, TIME FOR FILING
First party (i.e., Shipper’s own claims as opposed to third-party claims) claims for any delay, damage to, or loss of Crude Oil (“Claims”) must be made in writing to Carrier within nine (9) months after Delivery or, in the case of failure to make Delivery, then within nine (9) months after a reasonable time for Delivery has elapsed. Suits shall be instituted against Carrier only within two (2) years and one (1) day from the date when notice in writing is given by Carrier to the claimant that Carrier has disallowed the Claim or any part or parts thereof specified in the notice. Each Shipper and Carrier submits to the jurisdiction of any courts of the State of Wyoming in the County of Natrona, or of the United States District Court for the District of Wyoming. Each Party hereby (i) irrevocably waives any objection that it may now or hereafter have to the laying of venue, (ii) irrevocably waives and agrees not to plead or claim in any such court that any such action or proceeding brought therein has been brought in an inconvenient forum, and (iii) irrevocably and voluntarily waives right to a trial by jury in any action, proceeding or counterclaim arising out of, relating to, or in connection with this Tariff.

FERC ICA Oil Tariff F.E.R.C. No. 2.3.0 (Cancels F.E.R.C. 2.2.0)
GRIEVE PIPELINE, LLC (“Carrier”)
GRIEVE CRUDE OIL PIPELINE SYSTEM
LOCAL AND PROPORTIONAL PIPELINE RATES TARIFF
TRANSPORTED BY CARRIER’S PIPELINE FROM AND TO POINTS NAMED HEREIN
This Tariff shall apply to those Tariffs which specifically incorporate this Tariff by reference; such reference includes supplements to this Tariff and successive reissues thereof. Filed in accordance with 18 C.F.R. 342.3 (Indexing).
The rates and transportation fees named in this Tariff are expressed in cents per Barrel of 42 U.S. Gallons and are subject to change as provided by law.
The matter published herein will have no adverse effect on the quality of the human environment.
ISSUED: May 29, 2025 EFFECTIVE: July 1, 2025

LOCAL AND PROPORTIONAL PIPELINE RATES
The Receipt Point(s) on the Carrier’s Pipeline are:
· inlet flange at the Grieve Station on the Murphy Ranch Lease of Carrier’s Pipeline;
The Delivery Point(s) on the Carrier’s Pipeline are:
· the interconnection with Platte Pipe Line Company, LLC’s system near Casper, Wyoming;
This Tariff incorporates the terms and provisions, including the defined terms, set forth in the Rules and Regulation Tariff of Carrier’s Pipeline, labeled F.E.R.C. No. 1.0.0, as may be amended hereinafter.
A. Transportation Fee for Committed Shippers:
Table 1 – Transportation Fee for Committed Volumes (dollars per barrel) From To Rate
Receipt Point
Delivery Point
[I] $3.5500
The Transportation Fee shall be subject to adjustment annually beginning the second July 1st after the deliveries of Crude Oil commence on Carrier’s Pipeline, as promulgated by FERC in accordance with the FERC’s indexing methodology currently set forth at 18 C.F.R. § 342.3; provided, however, the transportation fee shall never be less than $3.00 per barrel.
B. Transportation Fee for Uncommitted Shippers:
Table 2 – Uncommitted Transportation Fee (dollars per barrel) From To Rate
Receipt Point
Delivery Point
[I] $3.5400
Grieve Pipeline, LLC F.E.R.C. No. 2.3.0 (Cancels F.E.R.C. No. 2.2.0) Page 3 of 3
C. Additional Fees
Each Shipper shall be subject to its pro rata share based on the volume of Crude Oil Tendered to Carrier of a fixed monthly fee to reimburse Carrier for the capital expenditures necessary to construct associated infrastructure connecting Carrier’s Pipeline to facilities at the Platte Pipeline Station at the Delivery Point (the “Interconnection Facilities”) in the amount determined by amortizing the actual cost of the construction of the Interconnection Facilities, with a return on investment, paid by Carrier over a period of ten (10) years. A Shipper shall be responsible for this fixed monthly fee each month it Tenders Crude Oil that Carrier transports.
Explanation of Reference Marks [I] Increased Rate
